newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: South African sugar strike talks to resume.
newsitem.headline: South African sugar strike talks to resume.

text.p: Talks to end a week-long South African sugar strike, which broke down on Monday, will resume on Tuesday at an undisclosed venue, a union spokesman said.
About 4,000 milling and refining workers have downed tools in protest against a wage increase offer of 10.5 percent by Illovo Sugar Ltd and Tongaat-Hulett Ltd.
Industry sources said about 83,500 tonnes of cane per day was being lost but they could not put a value on the figure.
A trade union official said on Tuesday that it was essential for the talks to continue to resolve the strike.
"We are all feeling the pinch now and it is important that we all come to the table and look at strategies to resolve this dispute," Food and Allied Workers' Union spokesman Zwile Zulu told Reuters.
"We will be meeting again today (Tuesday)," he added.
The current season's production has been estimated at 2.5 million tonnes with 48 percent being exported in the 1997/98 season, rising from 44 percent in 1996/97.
